results.title: CATARACT (concrete)
results.credit_line:
Daniel von Sturmer. Aotearoa New Zealand

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop

Commissioned by ACMI
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video
results.brief_description: Everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality.

constellations_primary.name: Now watch this
constellations_primary.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.headline_credit_for_label:
Australia, 2020

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop.
results.description:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.
description_for_label:

results.title: Cat's cradle = Au bout du fil
results.creator_credit: Paul Driessen, Gaston Sarault and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An animated fable without words starring some Gothic characters - witches, cloaked riders and the like - in a tale about the hungry natural world. Here the artist plays cat’s cradle with ideas, especially the notion that one thing leads to another and lives from another; he supports the action with a witch’s brew of sounds. Awards: Los Angeles; Zagreb
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Driessen, Gaston Sarault and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Castro's Cuba
results.creator_credit: Chris Sheridan, Keith Lambourne and Independent Television News (GB)
results.brief_description: Cuba has been embargoed by the USA, abandoned by Russia, is one of the remaining issues of the Cold War and is close to bankruptcy, but the citizens of the country still fervently support their leader Fidel Castro. This documentary tells the story of Castro’s rise to power, the revolution of 1959, his reform programmes and his program of relations with the world’s superpowers as well as regional neighbours. It also investigates why this charismatic man is so adored by his citizens and how he has maintained his ‘beloved’ status for so long.

results.title: Castle of the walking dead
results.brief_description: Based on Edgar Allen Poe’s story “The Pit and the pendulum”, this ghastly story stars Christopher Lee as Count Regula, who has dismembered twelve virgins. After thrity five years, his indestructible servant puts him together again and hes back at his favourite hobby once more. If your passion is horrific movies - this one is gory enough to satisfy even the strongest need.

results.title: Castle of Cagliostro [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Hayao Miyazaki, Tetsuo Katayama and Tokio Movie Shinsha Company
results.brief_description: The character of Lupin III, created by manga artist Monkey Punch, was already a pop culture icon in Japan when this film was released in 1980. Based on an earlier character—Maurice Leblanc’s dashing, turn-of-the-century gentleman thief, Arsene Lupin—the gadget wielding trickster Lupin III had appeared in comics, a television series and a previous feature film. In ‘The Castle of Cagliostro’ Miyazaki remains reasonably true to the original characters—he had written and directed some of the TV episodes himself—but his film also has the mark of a Miyazaki original. After performing a daring casino heist, Lupin and his sidekick discover the money they have stolen is counterfeit. Tracing the bills to the tiny European duchy of Cagliostro, Lupin immediately sets off with his partners in crime, a retired gangster, a modern-day samurai, and a beautiful female thief. Upon arrival they find themselves caught up in a fiendish plot involving counterfeit money, a hidden treasure, a princess locked away in the highest tower of a castle, and the evil Count Cagliostro. Flawlessly combining high action, broad comedy, romance, and mystery, with beautiful detailed animation, the film is considered a milestone in the anime genre. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Casterton lights up!
results.brief_description:
Casterton is a small rural town roughly half way between Melbourne and Adelaide, in far western Victoria. Like many smaller rural communities, Casterton has a rich agricultural history that claims not only to being the birthplace of the Kelpie but the first permanent inland Victorian settlement.
Due to a loss of both government and local industries during the nineties, Casterton found itself struggling to maintain its population. In April 1995, a public meeting was called to establish a survival plan. Attended by a hundred or so locals, the meeting produced a number of community initiatives including the developmentof a local phenomenon into a public festival.
In the eight years since, the annual Christmas lights festival has grown into the most important event on Casterton’s social calender. Today, two thirds of all homes in Casterton are lit each Christmas with up to 10,000 visitors passing through the town each December to take part in the nightly lights tours run by the local Lions Club
Casterton Lights Up! is an independently produced community documentary project written, directed, produced and funded by Melbourne Based filmmaker Glen Moore. The project was developed with the assistance and keen support of the Casterton community and aims to highlight the importance of community connectedness and spirit to the survival of small rural communities.

results.title: Carving Techniques and Projects
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the basics of gouge and chisel work, discussing the choice of tools, ideas and how to adjust designs. Shows how to carve the hallmark of 18th century furniture: the classic scallop shell.
results.description: Demonstrates the basics of gouge and chisel work, discussing the choice of tools, ideas and how to adjust designs. Shows how to carve the hallmark of 18th century furniture: the classic scallop shell.

results.title: Carve a Ball and Claw Foot
results.brief_description: Learn how to scale the ball-and-claw to furniture plan, how to machine stock to yield a graceful bandsaw cabriole leg ready for carving, how to lay out form, cut-in with a mallet and gouge and shape the dragon’s claw for a vigorous looking grip, how to carve efficiently, keeping tools sharp as you work.
results.description: Learn how to scale the ball-and-claw to furniture plan, how to machine stock to yield a graceful bandsaw cabriole leg ready for carving, how to lay out form, cut-in with a mallet and gouge and shape the dragon’s claw for a vigorous looking grip, how to carve efficiently, keeping tools sharp as you work.

results.title: Cartoon classics of the 30's
results.brief_description: A historic collection of classic animated cartoons from the 1930s including two very famous and much loved characters, Felix the Cat (The Goose that laid the golden egg) and Daffy Duck. Entertaining family viewing but also a fascinating look back at animation styles and techniques of the era. NB: Quality of sound and color is variable.

results.title: Caroline
results.creator_credit: Clement Perron, Georges Dufaux and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: To the public she is the pleasant, never-ruffled handler of everyone’s complaints at the telephone company. But behind her calm exterior the film reveals her doubts about her personal life, the domestic world of husband and child.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clement Perron, Georges Dufaux and National Film Board of Canada
